title: 113_s410
content: The Act is titled the "Wall Street Trading and Speculators Tax Act" and introduces a tax on trading transactions in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Wall Street Trading and Speculators Tax Act" imposes a 0.03 percent tax on covered transactions involving securities based on the fair market value or payment amount. Covered transactions include purchases cleared on a specified base amount. The "Wall Street Trading and Speculators Tax Act" imposes a 0.03 percent tax on covered transactions involving securities traded or cleared in the United States, or involving United States persons. The term 'security' includes shares of stock in a corporation, partnership interests, and beneficial ownership interests in partnerships or trusts. The "Wall Street Trading and Speculators Tax Act" defines various financial instruments including securities, derivative financial instruments, currency or commodity derivatives, and notional principal contracts. These instruments are subject to a 0.03 percent tax on covered transactions involving securities traded in the US or involving US persons. A notional principal contract is a financial instrument that involves multiple payments based on a specified index. The index can be a fixed rate, variable rate, or any objectively determinable information beyond the control of the parties involved. The tax treatment of exchanges involves treating them as sales and purchases of property by each party involved. Exceptions exist for initial issues, where no tax is imposed on covered transactions. The tax imposed on covered transactions for initial issuance of certain securities can be exempt under specific conditions, such as short-term indebtedness traded on a U.S. trading facility with a fixed maturity of 100 days or less. Additionally, securities lending arrangements where gain or loss is not recognized are also exempt from the tax. The tax imposed by this section is paid by the facility or broker involved in the transaction, with special rules for direct transactions where the purchaser is a United States person. Payments related to securities are treated as separate transactions, including initial, final, or periodical payments, as well as payments with respect to notional principal contracts, forward contracts, and options. Controlled foreign corporations are treated as United States persons for tax purposes. The tax payable by a controlled foreign corporation under subsection (g)(2) is instead paid by United States shareholders based on their proportion of stock ownership in the corporation. Definitions are provided for clarity. The Secretary will administer the section in consultation with the SEC and CFTC, providing guidance and regulations to prevent avoidance of reporting requirements for covered transactions involving non-US persons. The IRS will amend the tax code to include a new section regarding transactions involving non-US persons in tax-favored accounts. The IRS will amend the tax code to include a new section regarding transactions involving non-US persons in tax-favored accounts, including an offset for transaction tax. The new tax code section allows a credit of 0.03 percent of qualified tax-favored account contributions for the taxable year. Qualified contributions include amounts to retirement plans and Archer MSAs. The new tax code section allows deductions for health savings accounts, qualified tuition programs, and Coverdell education savings accounts for the taxable year.
